topic_rationale: Polycythemia Vera (PV) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by increased red blood cell mass. It is a classic teaching case for hematologic malignancies and is diagnostically challenging due to its diverse clinical manifestations.

explanations.tile_0: Polycythemia vera is characterized by an increased hematocrit due to overproduction of red blood cells.
explanations.tile_1: The majority of patients with Polycythemia Vera have a mutation in the JAK2 gene (V617F most common).
explanations.tile_2: Post-bath pruritus is a common symptom of Polycythemia Vera, likely due to increased histamine release from basophils.
explanations.tile_3: Erythromelalgia, or burning, painful erythema of the hands and feet, is a common symptom of Polycythemia Vera.
explanations.tile_4: Splenomegaly is frequently present in Polycythemia Vera due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
explanations.tile_5: In Polycythemia Vera, erythropoietin (EPO) levels are typically low or normal due to feedback inhibition from increased red cell mass.
explanations.tile_6: Patients with Polycythemia Vera are at an increased risk of thrombotic events.
explanations.tile_7: Bone marrow in Polycythemia Vera is hypercellular due to increased production of all three cell lines (panmyelosis).
explanations.tile_8: Absence of the Philadelphia chromosome (Ph1) helps to exclude chronic myeloid leukemia, which can present similarly to Polycythemia Vera.
